docs.title: Welcome to Mixy documentation
docs.text:
Here you can learn how to:

  • setup your device
  • choose software best suited for your use case
  • configure them to your liking

Documentation is far from complete.

docs.title: General
docs.text:
Why are you doing this?

Me and my friends just find it useful. Also it's pretty cool and reasonably sized portfolio project.

Is it open source?

Source code of every program developed for Mixy is or eventually will be free and open source. Licenses may change anytime.

However the hardware, so any CAD/EDA designs, is and will be closed.

Are you really selling it?

Somehow, sometimes, kinda.

docs.title: Hardware customization
docs.text:
Making Mixy fully your's

Mixy has two modes of operation:

  • slow mode
  • fast mode

The slow/fast terms refer to sampling frequency which directly influences the responsivness of knobs. The higher the frequency, the better response time, but higher battery usage.

They work like that:

  • start with slow mode (sampling frequency controlled by Slow Interval)
  • if knob change is detected, switch to fast mode
  • sampling frequency controlled by Fast Interval
  • if no changes detected for Fast Timeout, switch back to slow mode

Change Threshold parameter controls knob movement sensitivity, usually there is no reason to change it.

Based on above, you should understand that to save battery:

  1. Slow Interval needs to be high
  2. Fast Interval also needs to be high
  3. while Fast Timeout needs to be low

In the future, some kind of calculator/formula will be provided. But for now let's just say that 1. and 3. are much more important.

You can learn how to set these parameters for every program in corresponding setup guide.

docs.title: First connection with Mixy
docs.text: To connect with Mixy you need a device with BLE-capable Bluetooth adapter.

docs.title: Mixy Tester
docs.text:
With Mixy and Bluetooth enabled, first go to a Mixy Tester page. You need a Chromium-based browser for it to work, it can even be Chrome on Android.

There you can connect with Mixy and view its specs. If knobs are not yet displayed, turn one of them for all to appear.

On the bottom of the page you can play with Mixy's parameters. They allow balancing responsivness and power efficiency. To learn more, check out the customization guide.

docs.title: Installing software
docs.text:
To make any use of Mixy you need some software that can communicate with it.

Go to software selection to choose a dedicated program.

You can also use Mixy as a MIDI controller for any DAW or other music software. Some of them will connect via Bluetooth by themselves, others will need MIDI-BLE to MIDI bridge.

docs.title: Software selection
docs.text:
Currently, MixyLabs offers two software solutions dedicated for Mixy:

  • meej
  • Mixy Connect

docs.title: meej
docs.text:
meej is a background daemon with YAML config. Works on Windows and Linux.

Suitable for more technical people.

Download it from its releases page. Then, continue with its setup guide.

docs.title: Mixy Connect
docs.text:
⠀

Mixy Connect is in closed beta.

Mixy Connect is an addon to EarTrumpet. So it works only on Windows and has a nice GUI.

Suitable for everyone who has enough patience for GUI's.
